Explanations about Options.-d(M): Remove (delete) entries from a zip archive. For example:
Explanations about Options.-m(M):
Move the specified files into the zip archive; actually, this deletes the target
 directories/files after making the specified zip archive. If a directory becomes
 empty after removal of the files, the directory is also removed. No deletions are
 done until zip has created the archive without error. This is useful for
 conserving disk space, but is potentially dangerous so it is recommended to use it
 in combination with -T to test the archive before removing all input files.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Delete files from an existing zip file
Top-3 Scripts:
so_13697987: for file in $(find . -name "*.zip" -type f)
    do
      if [ -f $file".done" ];    then         #test if there is a done file for that zip
          unzip $file -d /home/b/file_input
          for filezip in `unzip -l $file | awk '/.xml$/{print $NF}'`; do  #creates the .done files for each file inside the zip
             touch /home/b/file_input/$filezip".done"
          done
          rm $file    
      fi
    done

so_22945785: pdf_list=( "/home/d/0    1.pdf" "/home/d/0    2.pdf" )

zip "$zip_path" "${pdf_list[@]}"
# ..............^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^   this syntax is crucial: use exactly like this

Explanations about Options.-p(M):
extract files to pipe (stdout). Nothing but the file data is sent to stdout , and
 the files are always extracted in binary format, just as they are stored (no
 conversions).

Explanations about Options.-x(M):
Extract files from an archive. Arguments are optional. When given, they specify
 names of the archive members to be extracted.

Top-3 Scripts:
su_561089: #!/bin/bash

read dirloc

cd $dirloc

for file in *.tar.7z
        do
                7za x -so $file | tar -xf -
        done

su_990333: tar -cf myzip.tar myfiles_*

tar -cfz myzip.tar.gz

tar -xf myzip.tar.gz
